discussion.content: old question. SSL 2 and 3 are deprecated now ? ELB supports TLS 1.3: https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2023/03/application-load-balancer-tls-1-3/

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticloadbalancing/latest/classic/elb-security-policy-table.html
A is the right answer.
Correct Answer: A
A. TLS 1.3

questions.question_text: A user has configured ELB with SSL using a security policy for secure negotiation between the client and load balancer. Which of the below mentioned SSL protocols is not supported by the security policy?
questions.answer_description:
Elastic Load Balancing uses a Secure Socket Layer (SSL. negotiation configuration which is known as a Security Policy. It is used to negotiate the SSL connections between a client and the load balancer. Elastic Load Balancing supports the following versions of the SSL protocol:

TLS 1.2 -

TLS 1.1 -

TLS 1.0 -

SSL 3.0 -
SSL 2.0

questions.question_text:
A user has created a VPC with the public and private subnets using the VPC wizard. The VPC has CIDR 20.0.0.0/16. The public subnet uses CIDR 20.0.1.0/24.
The user is planning to host a web server in the public subnet (port 80. and a DB server in the private subnet (port 3306). The user is configuring a security group for the public subnet (WebSecGrp. and the private subnet (DBSecGrp). Which of the below mentioned entries is required in the private subnet database security group (DBSecGrp)?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: A
By default the outbound will allow all , so all we have to do it's add the inbound so i will go with A. Also this is a typical question from SAA
Correct Answer is A

Correct Answer: A 
Please remember that security groups are statefull, so the outgoing rule is not necessary.
A is correct here. The question specifically asks about an entry for the DBSecGrp group.

C. This is a twist and turn question or the author is very poor in grammar. it is actually asking how to configure WebSecGrp to access DB, thus outbound port 3306 from WebSecGrp to destination DB is correct.

It woud help if you'd put a link or rationale for your answer. But you don't...ever.
Answer C.
The inbound rule in your security group must allow traffic on all ports. It needs to do this because the destination port number of any inbound return packets is set to a randomly allocated port number.
https://www.examtopics.com/exams/amazon/aws-sysops/view/
Also review a similarly worded question which supports answer of C.
https://www.briefmenow.org/amazon/aws-sysops-user-has-created-vpc-with-the-public-and-private-subnets-using-the-vpc-wizard-the-vpc-has-cidr-20-16-the-public-subnet-uses-cidr-20-24-the-user-is/
A. Allow Inbound on port 3306 for Source Web Server Security Group (WebSecGrp)

questions.answer_description: A user can create a subnet with VPC and launch instances inside that subnet. If the user has created a public private subnet to host the web server and DB server respectively, the user should configure that the instances in the private subnet can receive inbound traffic from the public subnet on the DB port. Thus, configure port 3306 in Inbound with the source as the Web Server Security Group (WebSecGrp). The user should configure ports 80 and 443 for Destination 0.0.0.0/0 as the route table directs traffic to the NAT instance from the private subnet.

choices.A: Allow Inbound on port 3306 for Source Web Server Security Group (WebSecGrp)
choices.B: Allow Inbound on port 3306 from source 20.0.0.0/16
choices.C: Allow Outbound on port 3306 for Destination Web Server Security Group (WebSecGrp)
choices.D: Allow Outbound on port 80 for Destination NAT Instance IP

questions.question_text: A user has created a VPC with CIDR 20.0.0.0/16 using the wizard. The user has created public and VPN only subnets along with hardware VPN access to connect to the user's data center. The user has not yet launched any instance as well as modified or deleted any setup. He wants to delete this VPC from the console. Will the console allow the user to delete the VPC?

discussion.content:
Just tested, the answer is B
You should detach gateway manually

comments.content:
The link you provided says you receive the errors when you try to delete the VPC using the CLI. The question asks what will happen if you use the console.
When you use the console the right answer is C

discussion.content:
Answer B
https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/troubleshoot-dependency-error-delete-vpc/

The following errors indicate that the Amazon VPC has a dependency: 

 "Network has some mapped public address(es). Please unmap those public address(es) before detaching the gateway." 
 "VPC has one or more attached internet gateways or virtual private gateways, and cannot be deleted until they are detached or deleted."
A. It will delete what it created since nothing was modified: subnets, route tables , network ACLs, security Groups,IGW and VGW

Selected Answer: B
Tested this in a lab, its B.

If i attached a Virtual Private Gateway, and i attempt to delete, i am told to manually detach it first before deleting

Ans is C....Concept is very simple
1. Created VPC using wizard - public and VPN subnet - no NAT instance
2. Created VPC using wizard - Public and private subnet - NAT instance will be there. so you need to delete that instance before deleting the VPC

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_wizard.html

This might help:
https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/troubleshoot-dependency-error-delete-vpc/

After some headache, I agree with awsnoob as D is correct.

Default when create VPC using wizard, NAT Gateway or NAT Instance is required.

Since question mentioned user not yet "deleted any setup", so the NAT Gateway/Instance is running. 

You can delete your VPC at any time. However, you must terminate all instances in the VPC, and delete any VPC peering connections first:

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/working-with-vpcs.html#VPC_Deleting.

Things inside VPC that you don't need to worry about when delete VPC

Virtual Private Gateways (the console will detach VPG from VPC )
VPN Attachments
Internet Gateways
Route Tables

comments.content: I revert back, "user has created public and VPN only subnets along with hardware VPN access" not " Private Public Wizard" as same as karmaah mentioned, so the NAT Gateway/Instance is not required. Hence, C is correct

The link you provided says you receive the errors when you try to delete the VPC using the CLI. The question asks what will happen if you use the console.
When you use the console the right answer is C

discussion.content: C. Yes, the console will delete all the setups and detach the virtual private gateway

comments.content:
The default Ansis correct.

If the virtual private gateway is attached with VPC and the user deletes the VPC from the console it will first detach the gateway automatically and only then delete the VPC.

discussion.content:
Answer is B, 
The VPC has one or more attached VPN gateways, and cannot be deleted until they are detached or deleted.

comments.content: NAT will run only on Private Public Wizard..Not for Private / Public subnet along with H/w VPN Wizard.

discussion.content: Ans is D, the wizard will need to specify the creation of the NAT gateway/instance

questions.answer_description: The user can create subnets as per the requirement within a VPC. If the user wants to connect VPC from his own data center, he can setup a public and VPN only subnet which uses hardware VPN access to connect with his data center. When the user has configured this setup with Wizard, it will create a virtual private gateway to route all traffic of the VPN subnet. If the virtual private gateway is attached with VPC and the user deletes the VPC from the console it will first detach the gateway automatically and only then delete the VPC.

choices.D: No, since the NAT instance is running
choices.B: No, the console will ask the user to manually detach the virtual private gateway first and then allow deleting the VPC
choices.C: Yes, the console will delete all the setups and detach the virtual private gateway
choices.A: Yes, the console will delete all the setups and also delete the virtual private gateway

comments.content:
B is a wrong answer. 
Because a subnet can only be in one AZ and the SG are associated with the subnet, so you need 2 SG.

The correct answer is C.

discussion.content:
B and C are both possible options.
As per B not necessarily both needs to be a part of same SG. So would go with C.
Letter C

questions.answer_description:
Even though ICMP is not a connection-oriented protocol, Security Groups are stateful. ג€Security groups are stateful ג€" responses to allowed inbound traffic are allowed to flow outbound regardless of outbound rules, and vice versaג€.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/UserGuide/VPC_SecurityGroups.html

choices.C: Yes, the security group for the monitoring instance needs to allow outbound ICMP and the application instance's security group needs to allow Inbound ICMP
choices.B: Yes, both the monitoring instance and the application instance have to be a part of the same security group, and that security group needs to allow inbound ICMP
choices.D: Yes, both the monitoring instance's security group and the application instance's security group need to allow both inbound and outbound ICMP ping packets since ICMP is not a connection-oriented protocol
choices.A: No, two instances in two different AZ's can't talk directly to each other via ICMP ping as that protocol is not allowed across subnet (iebroadcast) boundaries

questions.question_text:
Your entire AWS infrastructure lives inside of one Amazon VPC. You have an Infrastructure monitoring application running on an Amazon instance in Availability
Zone (AZ) A of the region, and another application instance running in AZ B. The monitoring application needs to make use of ICMP ping to confirm network reachability of the instance hosting the application.
Can you configure the security groups for these instances to only allow the ICMP ping to pass from the monitoring instance to the application instance and nothing else? If so how?
A user is trying to create a PIOPS EBS volume with 4000 IOPS and 100 GB size. AWS does not allow the user to create this volume. What is the possible root cause for this?

choices.C: The ratio between IOPS and the EBS volume is lower than 50
choices.B: The maximum IOPS supported by EBS is 3000
choices.A: The ratio between IOPS and the EBS volume is higher than 30
choices.D: PIOPS is supported for EBS higher than 500 GB size

questions.answer_description: A provisioned IOPS EBS volume can range in size from 10 GB to 1 TB and the user can provision up to 4000 IOPS per volume. The ratio of IOPS provisioned to the volume size requested should be a maximum of 30; for example, a volume with 3000 IOPS must be at least 100 GB.

discussion.content: new ratio is 50:1
A. The ratio between IOPS and the EBS volume is higher than 30

The description is Invalid or may be older update. It had been calcuated based on 30 or lower IOPS Provision capacity.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/ebs-volume-types.html#EBSVolumeTypes_piops.

An io1 volume can range in size from 4 GiB to 16 TiB.
If Nitro-based Instances then IOPS Can be 100 IOPS to 64000 IOPS.
If Non Nitro-based Instances then IOPS Can be 100 IOPS to 32000 IOPS.

The maximum ratio of provisioned IOPS to requested volume size (in GiB) is 50:1. 
As per question : 100GB so Max IOPS can be 5000.
